<@U0H6L5LQP>: Actually you can do it easily. By default Genymotion devices use a NAT connection to connect to internet. It means they are not visible from your local network. You can change this connection to a Bridged connection. This type of connection will let your local DHCP gives the Genymotion device’s IP, then you will be able to reach it from everywhere on your local netork.
Open VirtualBox app, choose the device you want to setup, open the settings > Network tab > Adapter 2 > Atttached to: "Bridged Adaptor” instead of “NAT"
Then just get your device’s IP and you’re all set
<@U0DTGSP8E>: if you only want it to show your icon it isn’t a FAB anymore and it going against the design guidelines

        fab:menu_colorPressed="#E75043"
        fab:menu_colorRipple="#99FFFFFF”
```

<@U0WPA1H28>: That for the most part is fine. However keep in mind if you are using the appcompat vector support you can run into issues inflating vector drawables when using the application context on api 19 and down

perfect example is the picasso placeholder. If you look at what they do . they take your provided context and strip it down to the application context which makes the app compat wrapping not work and you crash on getDrawable with a vector

Guys, about using DataBinding on a Library Gradle project.
Changed my build.gradle from "com.android.application" to "com.android.library" and databinding stopped generating its classes.
Any tips?

<@U0JBR7LUV>: unrelated to your crash but
```int w = getWidth();
int h = getHeight();```
you want to avoid allocating memory in `onDraw` to reduce the probability of garbage collection occurring
i think if you move the declaration of the variables into the class and re-use the `int`s that would clean it up

<@U0K1ALDQE>: what exactly you’d like to test? OnCreate, OnResume, orientation changes? You can do that with the instrumentation framework.
as opposed to robolectric it’ll create a real activity and perform shit with it, but the downside is you need to run it on an emulator.
<@U053PPGDC>: Yes, all of those. Thing is I used Robolectric for that, so I could do it in unit tests. But a lot of devs seem to advice against it
> as opposed to robolectric it’ll create a real activity and perform shit with it, but the downside is you need to run it on an emulator.
I know that, that’s why instrumentation is so slow
Anyhow, the standard instrumentation testing is not really good imhp
imho*
it’s not slow, on the haxm emulator or genymotion it’s real good
Even if I best use instrumentation test, what libs or substitutes do you use to improve it
well, most of that stuff is now in the testing support lib, which is waaaay nicer than the old instrumentation stuff
And btw instrumentation tests don’t work in a CI setup, do they?
they work wherever you can run an emulator.
main problem with emulators is that it takes real long time to start up the arm based emulator without hyper-v accelleration
you can however run it in a physical slave machine that either runs genymotion or haxm emulator or has a device connected, or use something like amazon device cloud or google cloud testing lab
google especially will allow you to either run your tests on emulators or real devices
but you need to pay for device minutes
